Reincarnation
It is fortunate that Dr. Detlev Bronk is no longer
here to witness the decaying response to the University
Lectures.
As a means whereby a Hopkins authority might
make known to the rest of the University community
developments in his specialty, the Lectures were instituted
in 1951 as part of the new Brorik Plan. •
The list of past speakers is impressive—William L.
Strauss, Simon Kuznets, W. Barry Wood, Sidney Painter,
George Boas, Benjamin H. Wither, Frederick C. Lane,
'Alsoph H. Corwin, Paul Linebarger, Lawton Wilkins,
G. Heberton Evans, Jr., and Ellis A. Johnson.
Their topics ranged from "Origin of Man" to "The
World's Crisis in Science and Technology."
However, when the Group Council decided to cancel
its series last year, it was pointed out that as few as
125 people had attended lectures the year before. At
that time there was uncertainty regarding the lecture
series' future.
This year witnesses a reincarnation of the Lectures.
Unlike many series, the University Lectures are not directed to an esoteric group but ard intended to be comprehensible to the -intelligent laymen.
We trust that these "intelligent laymen" will provide
something more than a token response next Wednesday.

Axe-Handling
The administrative axe at this University can be a
terrifying thing.- When it ig taken up, faculties •gape,
Councils tremble and heads roll.
When that axe is taken up merely because its wielder
has an itchy feeling for some kind of disciplinary justice,
the result can be devastating.
It can also -be downright repugnant.
The travesty of justice that took place last December

Reincarnation
It is fortunate that Dr. Detlev Bronk is no longer
here to witness the decaying response to the University
Lectures.
As a means whereby a Hopkins authority might
make known to the rest of the University community
developments in his specialty, the Lectures were instituted
in 1951 as part of the new Brorik Plan. •
The list of past speakers is impressive—William L.
Strauss, Simon Kuznets, W. Barry Wood, Sidney Painter,
George Boas, Benjamin H. Wither, Frederick C. Lane,
'Alsoph H. Corwin, Paul Linebarger, Lawton Wilkins,
G. Heberton Evans, Jr., and Ellis A. Johnson.
Their topics ranged from "Origin of Man" to "The
World's Crisis in Science and Technology."
However, when the Group Council decided to cancel
its series last year, it was pointed out that as few as
125 people had attended lectures the year before. At
that time there was uncertainty regarding the lecture
series' future.
This year witnesses a reincarnation of the Lectures.
Unlike many series, the University Lectures are not directed to an esoteric group but ard intended to be comprehensible to the -intelligent laymen.
We trust that these "intelligent laymen" will provide
something more than a token response next Wednesday.

Axe-Handling
The administrative axe at this University can be a
terrifying thing.- When it ig taken up, faculties •gape,
Councils tremble and heads roll.
When that axe is taken up merely because its wielder
has an itchy feeling for some kind of disciplinary justice,
the result can be devastating.
It can also -be downright repugnant.
The travesty of justice that took place last December
11 as a result of a student "revival" demonstration only
shows once again that our Dean of Students and certain
"student leaders" need a lesson in integrity and axehandling.
The results of DSRC hearings for five students and
administrative "approval" of the recommended penalties
as announced ,by DSRC president Stu Hanlein at a recent
Student Council meeting cloaks the truth and glosses
what is s unjust a piece of high-level skullduggery as
we've seen in years.
In the first place, the DSRC, though its hearing procedures were well-handled and suitably fair, made disciplinary recommendations which overstepped the boundaries of its jurisdiction. Only two student bodies on
this campus can make recommendations for a student's
academic suspension or expulsion: the Student Council
and the Honor Commission. In a case such as this where
an academic penalty is recommended, the Student Council
should be called in tO review and hear the.testimony.
But more important is the right of every individual
to a free trial, to determine not only the actuality of his
guilt but also the extent of it. When this right • is suppressed, as it was in the case of the sixth student whose
part in the proceedings was so carefully covered -up,
justice takes on a totalitarian quality.
The action of Dean Morrill in exacting sentence on
this student and thereby assuming the omnipotent role
of judge jury and executioner is a flagrant violation of
what must be to him an unknown concept—due process
of justice.
The puppet-figures who. hold positions of some authority in respect to the Dean of Students (namely the
Dormitory Counselor and president and certain members
of the DSRC) and whose 'presence at the scene of Dean
Morrill's minute-trial betokens a tacit, if not verbal approval of the whole matter, likewise deserve censure for
their action.
It is about time that the bullheaded tactics of selfappointed justiciars and the mishandling of justice which
has recurred so frequently in recent years be ended.
Student dissatisfaction is more than justified; it is long
overdue for its own hearing, without the threat of a
descending administrative axe.
